properties.Title: Special Air Quality Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: ROAD DUST ADVISORY IN EFFECT FOR SMITHERS AND VERNON The Ministry of Environment and Climate Change Strategy in collaboration with Northern Health has continued a Road Dust Advisory because of high concentrations of coarse particulate matter that are expected to persist until there is precipitation or dust suppression. Levels tend to be highest around busy roads and industrial operations. This advisory is in effect until further notice. Persons with chronic underlying medical conditions should postpone strenuous exercise near busy roads until the advisory is lifted. Exposure is particularly a concern for pregnant women, infants, the elderly and those who have diabetes, and lung or heart disease. Real-time air quality observations and information regarding the health effects of air pollution can be found at https://www2.gov.bc.ca/gov/content/environment/air-land-water/air ### For more information on current air quality, visit www2.gov.bc.ca/gov/content/environment/air-land-water/air. Visit www.airhealth.ca for information on how to reduce your health risk and your personal contribution to pollution levels, as well as for current and forecast AQHI values. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada.
Expires: 2020-03-23T22:21:06-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, the B.C. Ministry of Environment, 2020-03-23T06:22:06-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2213575964.2020
Area: North Okanagan, Bulkley Valley
properties.Author: Environment Canada, the B.C. Ministry of Environment

properties.Title: Winter Storm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Total snowfall: 15 to 20 cm. Maximum wind gusts: generally 80 km/h except 100 km/h over exposed areas. Locations: Bonavista Peninsula and Terra Nova. Time span: Tuesday afternoon until Wednesday evening. Remarks: Snow is expected to develop Tuesday afternoon and become heavy, at times, late overnight Tuesday night. The snow will be accompanied by strong northeasterly winds and reduced visibility in blowing snow overnight Tuesday night and Wednesday. Snow will become lighter Wednesday afternoon but strengthening northerly winds will continue to produce blowing snow until Wednesday evening. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Winter storm watches are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-03-24T10:19:30-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-23T18:20:30-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0936593195.2020
Area: Bonavista Peninsula, Terra Nova
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall and strong winds are expected. Total snowfall: 20 to 30 cm with higher amounts possible in some areas, especially over the Avalon Peninsula. Maximum wind gusts: 80 km/h except possibly up to 100 km/h over exposed areas. Locations: Avalon and Burin Peninsulas and Clarenville and vicinity. Time span: Tuesday evening until Wednesday evening. Remarks: Snow is expected to develop late in the day Tuesday, and will then become accompanied by strong northerly winds and reduced visibility in blowing snow early Wednesday morning. Snow will become lighter Wednesday afternoon but strengthening winds will continue to produce blowing snow until Wednesday evening. At this time there is some uncertainty regarding where the highest snowfall amounts will occur. Additional information will be provided as details become more certain. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-03-23T23:52:00-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-23T07:53:00-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.4222527373.2020
Area: Avalon Peninsula North, Avalon Peninsula Southeast, St. John's and vicinity, Avalon Peninsula Southwest, Burin Peninsula, Clarenville and vicinity
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 15 to 20 cm is expected. Total snowfall: 10 to 20 cm. Maximum wind gusts: 50 to 70 km/h. Locations: Victoria and Sydney Metro and Cape Breton counties. Time span: Tuesday morning until late Tuesday evening. Remarks: Snow is expected to start late Tuesday morning in Cape Breton. Snow may changeover or mix with rain in Sydney Metro and Cape Breton county in the afternoon, before switching back over to snow in the evening. Strong northerly winds will also accompany the snow Tuesday evening and continue overnight. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-24T10:44:11-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-23T18:45:11-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3553258930.2020
Area: Victoria County, Sydney Metro and Cape Breton County
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 10 to 15 cm continues. Heavy snow is falling over parts of the McGregor region. Snowfall accumulation totalling 10 to 15 cm is expected before the snow tapers to flurries this afternoon. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain, heavy at times is expected. The frozen ground has a reduced ability to absorb this rainfall. Total rainfall: 20 to 40 mm. Maximum wind gusts: 60 km/h. Locations: Atlantic coast of Nova Scotia. Time span: Tuesday morning until Tuesday evening. Remarks: A mix of rain and snow will begin in southwestern Nova Scotia early Tuesday morning and spread east throughout the morning. Higher snowfall totals of 5 to 10 cm are possible further inland before completely changing over to rain in the afternoon. Rain will taper off by Tuesday evening. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Be prepared for winter conditions at higher elevations. Rainfall warnings are issued when significant rainfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-24T10:50:37-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-23T18:51:37-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0837920019.2020

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 10 to 15 cm is expected. A disturbance forecast to develop over southern Alberta today will spread snow across the northern grainbelt of Saskatchewan tonight. Total snowfall amounts of 10 cm are possible over the area before tapering off late Tuesday afternoon. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to SKstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #SKStorm.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow, rain and wind on Tuesday. Total snowfall: 5 to 10 cm with more possible. Total rainfall: 10 to 25 mm with more possible. Maximum wind gusts: easterly 40 to 60 km/h. Location: Nova Scotia. Time span: Tuesday morning until Tuesday evening. Remarks: Snow will start Tuesday morning and then change to rain by late morning or afternoon over mainland Nova Scotia. The snow will mix with rain in the afternoon over southern Cape Breton. Rainfall warnings have been issued for parts of the Atlantic coast while snowfall warnings have been issued for parts of Cape Breton. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. Total snowfall: 20 to 30 cm. Maximum wind gusts: generally 80 km/h except 100 km/h over exposed areas. Locations: Burin Peninsula and Connaigre Peninsula Time span: midday Tuesday until Wednesday afternoon. Remarks: Snow is expected to develop midday Tuesday and become heavy, at times, Tuesday night. The snow will be accompanied by strong northeasterly winds and reduced visibility in blowing snow Tuesday night and Wednesday morning. The snow will become lighter Wednesday morning but strengthening northerly winds will continue to produce blowing snow until Wednesday afternoon. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-03-24T10:15:39-00:00

properties.Title: Weather Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Winter Weather Travel Advisory in effect for this morning. Flurries, heavy at times, will give some additional local amounts of 2 to 4 centimetres this morning before ending late this morning. Travel is expected to be hazardous at times due to local snowfall accumulation. Quickly changing and deteriorating travel conditions are expected. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. Total snowfall: 20 to 40 cm. Maximum wind gusts: generally 80 km/h except 100 km/h over exposed areas. Locations: Avalon Peninsula and Clarenville and vicinity. Time span: Tuesday afternoon until Wednesday evening. Remarks: Snow is expected to develop Tuesday afternoon and become heavy, at times, Tuesday night. The snow will be accompanied by strong northeasterly winds and reduced visibility in blowing snow Tuesday night and Wednesday. Snow will become lighter Wednesday afternoon but strengthening northerly winds will continue to produce blowing snow until Wednesday evening. Additionally, there is the potential for the snow to become mixed with or change over to rain or drizzle over portions of the Avalon Peninsula overnight Tuesday night and early Wednesday morning. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-03-24T10:17:24-00:00

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: The passage of a cold front is giving blizzard conditions to Rankin Inlet and Whale Cove. This blizzard will ease this afternoon or this evening as the winds slowly weaken. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: High southwesterlies reaching 90 kilometres per hour are affecting this area. The winds will abate around midday. ### Loose objects may be tossed by the wind and cause injury or damage. Wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A long period of snowfall with total amounts of 10 to 15 cm is expected. Snow will continue to push into Alberta today as a low pressure system develops in central Alberta. Snow will fall throughout the day today, before finally tapering off early Tuesday morning. For the Whitecourt region, areas north of Whitecourt are expected to receive snowfall totals of 10 to 15 cm whereas areas to the south, are not expected to receive such high totals. Areas near Hinton won't see heavier snowfall until later this afternoon. This warning may need to be expanded to other regions as the system continues to develop. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-24T08:35:49-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-23T16:36:49-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2202881489.2020
